verses.text: And when I had come to Rome I remained there until Anicetus, whose deacon was Eleutherus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:9
verses.text: And Anicetus was succeeded by Soter, and he by Eleutherus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:10
verses.text: In every succession, and in every city that is held which is preached by the law and the prophets and the Lord".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:11
verses.text: The same author also describes the beginnings of the heresies which arose in his time, in the following words: "And after James the Just had suffered martyrdom, as the Lord had also on the same account, Symeon, the son of the Lord's uncle, Clopas, was appointed the next bishop.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:12
verses.text: All proposed him as second bishop because he was a cousin of the Lord.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:13
verses.text: "Therefore, they called the Church a virgin, for it was not yet corrupted by vain discourses.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:14
verses.text: But Thebuthis, because he was not made bishop, began to corrupt it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:15
verses.text: He also was sprung from the seven sects among the people, like Simon, from whom came the Simonians, and Cleobius, from whom came the Cleobians, and Dositheus, from whom came the Dositheans, and Gorthaeus, from whom came the Goratheni, and Masbotheus, from whom came the Masbothaeans.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:16
verses.text: From them sprang the Menandrianists, and Marcionists, and Carpocratians, and Valentinians, and Basilidians, and Saturnilians.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:17
verses.text: Each introduced privately and separately his own peculiar opinion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:18
verses.text: From them came false Christs, false prophets, false apostles, who divided the unity of the Church by corrupt doctrines uttered against God and against his Christ".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:19
verses.text: The same writer also records the ancient heresies which arose among the Jews, in the following words: "There were, moreover, various opinions in the circumcision, among the children of Israel.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:20
verses.text: The following were those that were opposed to the tribe of Judah and the Christ: Essenes, Galileans, Hemerobaptists, Masbothaeans, Samaritans, Sadducees, Pharisees".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:21
verses.text: And he wrote of many other matters, which we have in part already mentioned, introducing the accounts in their appropriate places.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:22
verses.text: And from the Syriac Gospel according to the Hebrews he quotes some passages in the Hebrew tongue, showing that he was a convert from the Hebrews, and he mentions other matters as taken from the unwritten tradition of the Jews.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:23
verses.text: And not only he, but also Irenaeus and the whole company of the ancients, called the Proverbs of Solomon All-virtuous Wisdom.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:24
verses.text: And when speaking of the books called Apocrypha, he records that some of them were composed in his day by certain heretics.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 23:25
verses.text: But let us now pass on to another.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:2
verses.text: —Dionysius, Bishop of Corinth, and the Epistles which he wrote.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:3
verses.text: And first we must speak of Dionysius, who was appointed bishop of the church in Corinth, and communicated freely of his inspired labors not only to his own people, but also to those in foreign lands, and rendered the greatest service to all in the catholic epistles which he wrote to the churches.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:4
verses.text: Among these is the one addressed to the Lacedaemonians, containing instruction in the orthodox faith and an admonition to peace and unity; the one also addressed to the Athenians, exciting them to faith and to the life prescribed by the Gospel, which he accuses them of esteeming lightly, as if they had almost apostatized from the faith since the martyrdom of their ruler Publius, which had taken place during the persecutions of those days.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:5
verses.text: He mentions Quadratus also, stating that he was appointed their bishop after the martyrdom of Publius, and testifying that through his zeal they were brought together again and their faith revived.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:6
verses.text: He records, moreover, that Dionysius the Areopagite, who was converted to the faith by the apostle Paul, according to the statement in the Acts of the Apostles, first obtained the episcopate of the church at Athens.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:7
verses.text: And there is extant another epistle of his addressed to the Nicomedians, in which he attacks the heresy of Marcion, and stands fast by the canon of the truth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:8
verses.text: Writing also to the church that is in Gortyna, together with the other parishes in Crete, he commends their bishop Philip, because of the many acts of fortitude which are testified to as performed by the church under him, and he warns them to be on their guard against the aberrations of the heretics.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:9
verses.text: And writing to the church that is in Amastris, together with those in Pontus, he refers to Bacchylides and Elpistus, as having urged him to write, and he adds explanations of passages of the divine Scriptures, and mentions their bishop Palmas by name.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:10
verses.text: He gives them much advice also in regard to marriage and chastity, and commands them to receive those who come back again after any fall, whether it be delinquency or heresy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:11
verses.text: Among these is inserted also another epistle addressed to the Cnosians, in which he exhorts Pinytus, bishop of the parish, not to lay upon the brethren a grievous and compulsory burden in regard to chastity, but to have regard to the weakness of the multitude.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:12
verses.text: Pinytus, replying to this epistle, admires and commends Dionysius, but exhorts him in turn to impart some time more solid food, and to feed the people under him, when he wrote again, with more advanced teaching, that they might not be fed continually on these milky doctrines and imperceptibly grow old under a training calculated for children.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:13
verses.text: In this epistle also Pinytus' orthodoxy in the faith and his care for the welfare of those placed under him, his learning and his comprehension of divine things, are revealed as in a most perfect image.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:14
verses.text: There is extant also another epistle written by Dionysius to the Romans, and addressed to Soter, who was bishop at that time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:15
verses.text: We cannot do better than to subjoin some passages from this epistle, in which he commends the practice of the Romans which has been retained down to the persecution in our own days.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:16
verses.text: His words are as follows:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:17
verses.text: "For from the beginning it has been your practice to do good to all the brethren in various ways, and to send contributions to many churches in every city.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:18
verses.text: Thus relieving the want of the needy, and making provision for the brethren in the mines by the gifts which you have sent from the beginning, you Romans keep up the hereditary customs of the Romans, which your blessed bishop Soter has not only maintained, but also added to, furnishing an abundance of supplies to the saints, and encouraging the brethren from abroad with blessed words, as a loving father his children".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:19
verses.text: In this same epistle he makes mention also of Clement's epistle to the Corinthians, showing that it had been the custom from the beginning to read it in the church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:20
verses.text: His words are as follows: "To-day we have passed the Lord's holy day, in which we have read your epistle.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:21
verses.text: From it, whenever we read it, we shall always be able to draw advice, as also from the former epistle, which was written to us through Clement".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:22
verses.text: The same writer also speaks as follows concerning his own epistles, alleging that they had been mutilated: "As the brethren desired me to write epistles, I wrote.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:23
verses.text: And these epistles the apostles of the devil have filled with tares, cutting out some things and adding others.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:24
verses.text: For them a woe is reserved.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:25
verses.text: It is, therefore, not to be wondered at if some have attempted to adulterate the Lord's writings also, since they have formed designs even against writings which are of less account".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:26
verses.text: There is extant, in addition to these, another epistle of Dionysius, written to Chrysophora, a most faithful sister.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:27
verses.text: In it he writes what is suitable, and imparts to her also the proper spiritual food.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 24:28
verses.text: So much concerning Dionysius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 25:2
verses.text: —Theophilus Bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 25:3
verses.text: Of Theophilus, whom we have mentioned as bishop of the church of Antioch, three elementary works addressed to Autolycus are extant; also another writing entitled Against the Heresy of Hermogenes, in which he makes use of testimonies from the Apocalypse of John, and finally certain other catechetical books.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 25:4
verses.text: And as the heretics, no less then than at other times, were like tares, destroying the pure harvest of apostolic teaching, the pastors of the churches everywhere hastened to restrain them as wild beasts from the fold of Christ, at one time by admonitions and exhortations to the brethren, at another time by contending more openly against them in oral discussions and refutations, and again by correcting their opinions with most accurate proofs in written works.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 25:5
verses.text: And that Theophilus also, with the others, contended against them, is manifest from a certain discourse of no common merit written by him against Marcion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 25:6
verses.text: This work too, with the others of which we have spoken, has been preserved to the present day.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 25:7
verses.text: Maximinus, the seventh from the apostles, succeeded him as bishop of the church of Antioch.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 26:2
verses.text: —Philip and Modestus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 26:3
verses.text: Philip who, as we learn from the words of Dionysius, was bishop of the parish of Gortyna, likewise wrote a most elaborate work against Marcion, as did also Irenaeus and Modestus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 26:4
verses.text: The last named has exposed the error of the man more clearly than the rest to the view of all.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 26:5
verses.text: There are a number of others also whose works are still presented by a great many of the brethren.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:2
verses.text: —Melito and the Circumstances which he records.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:3
verses.text: In those days also Melito, bishop of the parish in Sardis, and Apolinarius, bishop of Hierapolis, enjoyed great distinction.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:4
verses.text: Each of them on his own part addressed apologies in behalf of the faith to the above-mentioned emperor of the Romans who was reigning at that time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:5
verses.text: The following works of these writers have come to our knowledge.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:6
verses.text: Of Melito, the two books On the Passover, and one On the Conduct of Life and the Prophets, the discourse On the Church, and one On the Lord's Day, still further one On the Faith of Man, and one On his Creation, another also On the Obedience of Faith, and one On the Senses; besides these the work On the Soul and Body, and that On Baptism, and the one On Truth, and On the Creation and Generation of Christ; his discourse also On Prophecy, and that On Hospitality; still further, The Key, and the books On the Devil and the Apocalypse of John, and the work On the Corporeality of God, and finally the book addressed to Antoninus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:7
verses.text: In the books On the Passover he indicates the time at which he wrote, beginning with these words: "While Servilius Paulus was proconsul of Asia, at the time when Sagaris suffered martyrdom, there arose in Laodicea a great strife concerning the Passover, which fell according to rule in those days; and these were written".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:8
verses.text: And Clement of Alexandria refers to this work in his own discourse On the Passover, which, he says, he wrote on occasion of Melito's work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:9
verses.text: But in his book addressed to the emperor he records that the following events happened to us under him: "For, what never before happened, the race of the pious is now suffering persecution, being driven about in Asia by new decrees.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:10
verses.text: For the shameless informers and coveters of the property of others, taking occasion from the decrees, openly carry on robbery night and day, despoiling those who are guilty of no wrong".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:11
verses.text: And a little further on he says: "If these things are done by thy command, well and good.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:12
verses.text: For a just ruler will never take unjust measures; and we indeed gladly accept the honor of such a death.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:13
verses.text: But this request alone we present to thee, that thou wouldst thyself first examine the authors of such strife, and justly judge whether they be worthy of death and punishment, or of safety and quiet.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:14
verses.text: But if, on the other hand, this counsel and this new decree, which is not fit to be executed even against barbarian enemies, be not from thee, much more do we beseech thee not to leave us exposed to such lawless plundering by the populace".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:15
verses.text: Again he adds the following: "For our philosophy formerly flourished among the Barbarians; but having sprung up among the nations under thy rule, during the great reign of thy ancestor Augustus, it became to thine empire especially a blessing of auspicious omen.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:16
verses.text: For from that time the power of the Romans has grown in greatness and splendor.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:17
verses.text: To this power thou hast succeeded, as the desired possessor, and such shalt thou continue with thy son, if thou guardest the philosophy which grew up with the empire and which came into existence with Augustus; that philosophy which thy ancestors also honored along with the other religions.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:18
verses.text: And a most convincing proof that our doctrine flourished for the good of an empire happily begun, is this—that there has no evil happened since Augustus' reign, but that, on the contrary, all things have been splendid and glorious, in accordance with the prayers of all.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:19
verses.text: Nero and Domitian, alone, persuaded by certain calumniators, have wished to slander our doctrine, and from them it has come to pass that the falsehood has been handed down, in consequence of an unreasonable practice which prevails of bringing slanderous accusations against the Christians.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:20
verses.text: But thy pious fathers corrected their ignorance, having frequently rebuked in writing many who dared to attempt new measures against them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:21
verses.text: Among them thy grandfather Adrian appears to have written to many others, and also to Fundanus, the proconsul and governor of Asia.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:22
verses.text: And thy father, when thou also wast ruling with him, wrote to the cities, forbidding them to take any new measures against us; among the rest to the Larissaeans, to the Thessalonians, to the Athenians, and to all the Greeks.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:23
verses.text: And as for thee,—since thy opinions respecting the Christians are the same as theirs, and indeed much more benevolent and philosophic,—we are the more persuaded that thou wilt do all that we ask of thee".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:24
verses.text: These words are found in the above-mentioned work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:25
verses.text: But in the Extracts made by him the same writer gives at the beginning of the introduction a catalogue of the acknowledged books of the Old Testament, which it is necessary to quote at this point.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:26
verses.text: He writes as follows:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:27
verses.text: "Melito to his brother Onesimus, greeting: Since thou hast often, in thy zeal for the word, expressed a wish to have extracts made from the Law and the Prophets concerning the Saviour and concerning our entire faith, and hast also desired to have an accurate statement of the ancient book, as regards their number and their order, I have endeavored to perform the task, knowing thy zeal for the faith, and thy desire to gain information in regard to the word, and knowing that thou, in thy yearning after God, esteemest these things above all else, struggling to attain eternal salvation.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:28
verses.text: Accordingly when I went East and came to the place where these things were preached and done, I learned accurately the books of the Old Testament, and send them to thee as written below.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:29
verses.text: Their names are as follows: Of Moses, five books: Genesis, Exodus, Numbers, Leviticus, Deuteronomy; Jesus Nave, Judges, Ruth; of Kings, four books; of Chronicles, two; the Psalms of David, the Proverbs of Solomon, Wisdom also, Ecclesiastes, Song of Songs, Job; of Prophets, Isaiah, Jeremiah; of the twelve prophets, one book; Daniel, Ezekiel, Esdras.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:30
verses.text: From which also I have made the extracts, dividing them into six books".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 27:31
verses.text: Such are the words of Melito.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 28:2
verses.text: —Apolinarius, Bishop of the Church of Hierapolis.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 28:3
verses.text: A number of works of Apolinarius have been preserved by many, and the following have reached us: the Discourse addressed to the above-mentioned emperor, five books Against the Greeks, On Truth, a first and second book, and those which he subsequently wrote against the heresy of the Phrygians, which not long afterwards came out with its innovations, but at that time was, as it were, in its incipiency, since Montanus, with his false prophetesses, was then laying the foundations of his error.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 29:2
verses.text: —Musanus and His Writings.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 29:3
verses.text: And as for Musanus, whom we have mentioned among the foregoing writers, a certain very elegant discourse is extant, which was written by him against some brethren that had gone over to the heresy of the so-called Encratites, which had recently sprung up, and which introduced a strange and pernicious error.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 29:4
verses.text: It is said that Tatian was the author of this false doctrine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:2
verses.text: —The Heresy of Tatian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:3
verses.text: He is the one whose words we quoted a little above in regard to that admirable man, Justin, and whom we stated to have been a disciple of the martyr.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:4
verses.text: Irenaeus declares this in the first book of his work Against Heresies, where he writes as follows concerning both him and his heresy:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:5
verses.text: "Those who are called Encratites, and who sprung from Saturninus and Marcion, preached celibacy, setting aside the original arrangement of God and tacitly censuring him who made male and female for the propagation of the human race.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:6
verses.text: They introduced also abstinence from the things called by them animate, thus showing ingratitude to the God who made all things.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:7
verses.text: And they deny the salvation of the first man.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:8
verses.text: But this has been only recently discovered by them, a certain Tatian being the first to introduce this blasphemy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:9
verses.text: He was a hearer of Justin, and expressed no such opinion while he was with him, but after the martyrdom of the latter he left the Church, and becoming exalted with the thought of being a teacher, and puffed up with the idea that he was superior to others, he established a peculiar type of doctrine of his own, inventing certain invisible aeons like the followers of Valentinus, while, like Marcion and Saturninus, he pronounced marriage to be corruption and fornication.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:10
verses.text: His argument against the salvation of Adam, however, he devised for himself".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:11
verses.text: Irenaeus at that time wrote thus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:12
verses.text: But a little later a certain man named Severus put new strength into the aforesaid heresy, and thus brought it about that those who took their origin from it were called, after him, Severians.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:13
verses.text: They, indeed, use the Law and Prophets and Gospels, but interpret in their own way the utterances of the Sacred Scriptures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:14
verses.text: And they abuse Paul the apostle and reject his epistles, and do not accept even the Acts of the Apostles.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:15
verses.text: But their original founder, Tatian, formed a certain combination and collection of the Gospels, I know not how, to which he gave the title Diatessaron, and which is still in the hands of some.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:16
verses.text: But they say that he ventured to paraphrase certain words of the apostle, in order to improve their style.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:17
verses.text: He has left a great many writings.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:18
verses.text: Of these the one most in use among many persons is his celebrated Address to the Greeks, which also appears to be the best and most useful of all his works.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:19
verses.text: In it he deals with the most ancient times, and shows that Moses and the Hebrew prophets were older than all the celebrated men among the Greeks.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 30:20
verses.text: So much in regard to these men.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 31:2
verses.text: —Bardesanes the Syrian and his Extant Works.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 31:3
verses.text: In the same reign, as heresies were abounding in the region between the rivers, a certain Bardesanes, a most able man and a most skillful disputant in the Syriac tongue, having composed dialogues against Marcion's followers and against certain others who were authors of various opinions, committed them to writing in his own language, together with many other works.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 31:4
verses.text: His pupils, of whom he had very many (for he was a powerful defender of the faith), translated these productions from the Syriac into Greek.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 31:5
verses.text: Among them there is also his most able dialogue On Fate, addressed to Antoninus, and other works which they say he wrote on occasion of the persecution which arose at that time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 31:6
verses.text: He indeed was at first a follower of Valentinus, but afterward, having rejected his teaching and having refuted most of his fictions, he fancied that he had come over to the more correct opinion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 31:7
verses.text: Nevertheless he did not entirely wash off the filth of the old heresy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book IVs 31:8
verses.text: About this time also Soter, bishop of the church of Rome, departed this life.
